body.p: New Orleans October 24th/63.
To Revd. Isaac Lesser
Editor “Occident”
Revd. Sir!

Excuse my giving vent to painful feeling
which I can not restrain any longer. Can a son be silent
when he sees his father slighted by one whose respect and
admiration he deserves? Remember Revd Sir, how often
my venerable father appeared before the bar of public
opinion to advocate and defend you against the rude at=
tacks of Dr. Wise & Co.! Remember how often
my father proclaimed you in all the Jewish periodicals
as the only faithful advocate of true Judaism, as the
restorer of our Religion and Gonfalonier? of truth in this
country! But you have not a single word to say in
his favor, when his enemies try to slander him by false
and unfounded reports. You asked some time ago, for the
reasons of his leaving New Orleans, and I gave you
pure wine, the pure truth, without the least admixture
of untruth: what did you however write about it? You only
heaped slander upon slander; you wrote, “you received a
communication in favor of Dr. Illowy, but you have no
trust in it”, this is the essence, if not the words of your
report. You have no trust in my father's good character, (may
I presume Revd Sir to inquire, what is the cause of this doubt)
though you had already been informed by the Secretary of
the Cong in Cincinnati, that in spite of the malicious report

published in the Deborah, my father was unanimously, not one
voice dissenting, elected, and not by vote but by acclamation.
Why not one voice against him? Why so most honorably elected,
Because the people in Cincinnati heard from most trustworthy
men from New Orleans, that my father resigned his situa=
tion for the only reason, that he would not sell his conscience
for money.

You read the remarks of Revd. Isaacs; still you
doubted. It was not unknown to you that the friends of my
father in New Orleans had presented him when leaving this
City with a most costly silver pitcher and waiter; still you
doubted, ignoring all these evidences. You know my father
since fifteen years, you know him firm as a rock; he never
changed or altered his principles from fear of losing or for the
sake of making money as your friends in Hartford,
Rochester and other places have done. No! My father
fears nothing, he has his trust in God, and when he trust=
fully gave up his situation and my Dear mother lamented what
will we do now, he said with King David אוכל טרפה בפרהסיה
הפורשים מדרכי האחרונה והאחת והמוכרים אמונתם בעד ככר לחם.

Your remarks in the last number of the Occident did
not hurt neither me (though I felt bad) nor my honored fa=
ther; thank God, he stands above the level of all his enemies
neither did they give you any credit for them
your best friends
blamed you and laughed at you saying: “Mr Lesser is afraid
of spoiling his game with either party, especially with Gutheim
though he is an איש כשר וראויה להיות מגן הדור ונשיא בישראל; would Lesser be with twenty
years younger he would yet become the advocate of reform.
Let me ask you Mr Lesser, you congratulated Hartford

to the successful election of mayor, Rochester of Grinsburg?
St Louis of Vidaver, though you know all these formen
well, that they are men זרח לך אשת וכו
תלמוד מתלמיד כל עם הרשע; still you flattered these men, promised the world a
great future which judaism had to expect from them, and
how much good the respective congregations will derive from
the activity of these Rabbis. You knew Vidaver better
than any man in St. Louis, still you recommended him
as an מקוה שבחו בא לידי גנותו. He is a strict orthodox
You had to advocate him. Send your ears to St. Louis and
you will hear what he is; a religion maker and a גרים he was
long ago for he fulfilled the word שם ובמרחקים.

How much had you to say and how much good did you promise
that the Cong. of San Francisco had to expect, when they elected
Cohen, who was well known as a ואני נותרתי לבדי נביא להם; but you
had nothing, not a single word to say when Dr. Illowy was elected
by the Cong. in Cincinnati, and not alone that, but in the secretary's
report published in your paper, you malignantly left out the word
“unanimously”. You will find it in the “Messenger and Israelite,”
and your remark on an other page was more slander than praise,
it was such a praise as slanders bestow, צדיק

Thank God my father is too well known in the old and
new word as to stand in need of the praise of any american
journalist.

Yes my dear Sir, if you had something to say against my
father, you would be immediately at hand to condemn him or to
kindle the flame of discord against him.

When my father had the courage to declare a rich פושעים
you forgot yourself and dared set up your judgement against him.

Still my father did not use the expression which Wise
used several times against you and Isaacs; my father is too
pious, too honorable and too much of a gentleman. It was
satisfaction enough for him if five learned Rabbies, the
greatest men in, and the lights of, Israel, Seligman Bamberger
of Würzburg, Dr Hinsch, Franfort, Dr Lehman Mainz
Dr Tilchenfeld Düsseldorf, and Dr Hildesheimer Eisenstadt
all of them, like one voice, came out spontaneously, without being
called upon, and approved the action of my father in the most
laudable terms.

When my father wrote against the manufactory of לכבוד עצמו, who
dared come out against him, with argument founded not upon
Hebrew, but upon “COMMON SENSE”—Isaac Lesser”. Just as
if my father would be a thorn in your eye because he can say
with Elijah Hebrew; because he is the only Ortho=
dox Rabby in this country you would like to see him pushed
aside. Oh! great righteousness!—

Believe me Sir, that I am convinced that my worthy
father whom I expect home every day would not approve of
my letter, for when he sent you just before leaving N. O.
your $20.00, I told him to write you the cause of his
leaving N. O. since you once remarked that you would like
to know it, he answered, I do not wish to be heralded as Hebrew
let the world think every one just as he pleases. I however
can not see the man, who pretends to be the advocate, the champion
of Orthodoxy, play a false game, recommend Hebrew to orthodox
Congs. As if you would not know them better.

How great was your joy and hope when Cohen went to
San Francisco, but you are stricken with blindness and deafness

when you should come out with the truth. I confess it, that when
my father wrote us last week from Cincinnati; that Dr. Wise,
when seeing that the people in Cincinnati rush from all the Synagogues
to hear him and that the crowd in his synagogue is so great every
Sabbath that many must remain in the vestibule for want of room
withing and that his (Wise's) reports were declared, by the most respectable
men of this city who passed through there, as contrary to the truth
he began to make friendship with him and invited him to assist him
(Dr. Wise) in performing the marriage ceremonies at the wedding of his
daughter which will take place on the 1st. inst. and which invitation
was accepted by my father should he be present in Cincinnati, that
I thought at first of bringing this letter to your notice through
the columns of the Israelite, but knowing that my father would
disapprove it, for he never likes to come out publicly against any one,
if it is only Hebrew and not for the sake of religion, therefore
I took this method and speak to you like man to man.

Hoping that you may be able to answer satisfactorily
all these questions
I remain Revd Sir
your most obedient Servt.
